title: Tonkotsu Ramen (Hakata Style Complete Bowl)

ingredients.name: Bare Bones Shio Tare or Lighter Shoyu Tare

steps: Preheat your serving bowl by placing it in a 170°F (77°C) oven, or by filling it with hot water.
Prepare all toppings and have them ready (slice chashu, halve eggs, prepare wood ear mushrooms, slice green onions).
Bring a large pot of water to a rapid boil for cooking the noodles.
Heat the Tonkotsu Soup to a simmer.
When ready to assemble, empty the preheated bowl and add the Bare Bones Shio Tare or Lighter Shoyu Tare (30g) to the bottom of the bowl.
Add the All-Purpose Negi (Scallion) Oil (15g) to the bowl.
Add the hot Tonkotsu Soup (300g) to the bowl and stir to combine the tare and oil.
Cook the Makeshift-Hakata Style Noodles (130g) in the boiling water according to the noodle recipe instructions (typically very quick, 30-60 seconds for thin noodles).
When noodles are done, immediately drain them thoroughly in a fine mesh strainer, shaking vigorously to remove excess water.
Add the drained noodles to the bowl of soup. Use chopsticks to separate and arrange the noodles if desired.

Add toppings: place chashu at 6 o'clock position, egg at 11-12 o'clock, wood ear mushrooms and pickled ginger on the sides, green onions in the center, and nori at 1-2 o'clock (add nori last as it gets soggy quickly).
notes: Component recipes needed: tonkotsu-soup, bare-bones-shio-tare or lighter-shoyu-tare, all-purpose-negi-scallion-oil, makeshift-hakata-style-noodle
Prepare all component recipes in advance before assembly.
Classic Hakata-style tonkotsu features a rich, creamy pork bone broth.
Use shio tare to preserve the milky white color of the tonkotsu soup, or use shoyu tare if you prefer a darker color.
Hakata-style noodles are very thin and cook quickly - watch them carefully to avoid overcooking.
In Hakata, it's traditional to order kaedama (noodle refills) to add to the remaining soup.
30 mL of tare equals approximately 30g, 15 mL of oil equals approximately 15g, 300 mL of soup equals approximately 300g.
